    Enrichment

    enrichment.Rmd

    Term Enrichment

    Term enrichment analysis is possible proceeding an expression analysis with the enrichment() function, employing either the GSEA algorithm or a simple Wilcoxon rank sum comparison, and can be visualized with the plot_enrichment() function.

    library("dplyr")
library("tidyproteomics")

rdata <- hela_proteins %>% 
  normalize(.method = 'linear') %>%
  impute(impute_function = base::min) %>%
  expression(knockdown/control) %>%
  enrichment(knockdown/control, 
             .term = 'biological_process', 
             .method = 'wilcoxon')

    Exporting Results

    The results of this analysis are stored in the tidyproteomics data-object and can easily be exported to save as a flat data table or used in an external down stream analysis.

    
rdata %>% export_analysis(knockdown/control, 
                          .analysis = 'enrichment', 
                          .term = 'biological_process')
#> # A tibble: 13 Ã— 5
#>    annotation                          p_value adj_p_value enrichment  size
#>    <chr>                                 <dbl>       <dbl>      <dbl> <int>
#>  1 conjugation                      0.00000514   0.0000668     -14.6   1242
#>  2 cell proliferation               0.000167     0.00201        17.8    309
#>  3 development                      0.00235      0.0259        -15.5    898
#>  4 cellular component movement      0.00427      0.0427          6.77  1026
#>  5 cell differentiation             0.0147       0.132           5.98   560
#>  6 cellular homeostasis             0.0346       0.277           2.51  2988
#>  7 defense response                 0.0616       0.431          -8.36   869
#>  8 cell organization and biogenesis 0.114        0.684          -1.51  1397
#>  9 coagulation                      0.224        1              -1.87   981
#> 10 cell growth                      0.491        1              -2.49  1806
#> # â€¦ with 3 more rows

    The results can also have any other terms appended to the output, such as protein or gene_name, which may be useful for follow-on analyses.

    
rdata %>% export_analysis(knockdown/control, 
                          .analysis = 'enrichment', 
                          .term = 'biological_process',
                          .append = 'gene_name')
#> # A tibble: 13 Ã— 6
#>    annotation                          p_value adj_p_value enricâ€¦Â¹  size gene_â€¦Â²

    Enrichment Plot 

    
rdata %>% plot_enrichment(knockdown/control, 
                          .term = 'biological_process')
